nl.vu.pp.sequential
Class FifteenPuzzle

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--nl.vu.pp.sequential.FifteenPuzzle
public class FifteenPuzzle
extends java.lang.Object

This is a sequential implementation of the famous 15-puzzle by Sam Loyd, a recreational mathematician in the 19th century.

It contains a single-threaded implementation of the Iterative Deepening A-Star, Depth-First algorithm (IDA*) [Korf, 1985] that looks for the optimal solutions for a given board.
The program is run from this class and takes a plain text file that contains a board layout as argument and optionally a specific goal configuration.
The program will first estimate the minimal number of required moves and use the heuristic as the initial bound for the IDA* algorithm. If no solution is found, the heuristic is incremented by 2 (property of Manhattan distances, the applied heuristic) and the algorithm is restarted.

Be careful when supplying randomized board configurations as not every configuration can be solved.
If we consider the empty slot as a tile, there are 16 choices for the top left square, 15 for the second, 14 for the 3rd, etc. i.e. 16! arrangements in total. Without picking up tiles (i.e. sliding only), only half of these positions are achievable from any starting configuration - still a very large number indeed.

Author:
Erik van Zijst - erik@prutser.cx - 28.dec.2002

Method Detail

main

public static void main(java.lang.String[] argv)
                 throws java.lang.Exception
This method runs the program.
Start the application like this: 

   $ java nl.vu.pp.FifteenPuzzle -board board.txt [-solution solution.txt]

If a destination layout is not provided explicitly through the -solution parameter, the program uses this default goal layout:

 123
4567
891011
12131415

Throws:
java.lang.Exception - all exceptions that are raised in the application are uncatched and as a consequence will cause the main() method to exit with a stacktrace.

addSolution

public static void addSolution(Move move)
When the IDA* algorithm as implemented in the Job class finds a solution, this method is invoked together with the move that solved the game (note that every Move includes its parent move).
Currently, this method just prints the solution to stdout and increments the number of solutions.

Parameters:
move - the Move that solved the game.

boardToString

public static java.lang.String boardToString(int[][] _board,
                                             java.lang.String title)
This method takes a two-dimensional board array and formats it to a human-readable string that could be printed to the console or a file. The board will be formatted like this: 

   title-string
   10      13              12
   14      5       9       4
   6       1       8       2
   15      11      7       3

Parameters:
_board - a two-dimensional board array.
title - this string will be the board's caption.
Returns:
the human-readable formatted board.

getTotalDistance

public static int getTotalDistance(int[][] board,
                                   int[][] solution)
Takes both a shuffled board and its goal position and calculates the minimum amount of moves that are required to solve the puzzle.
Note that this "minimum cost" is highly optimistic as it is derived from the manhattan distances of all individual tiles.

Parameters:
board - the shuffled board.
solution - the board's goal position.
Returns:
the minimum amount of moves that are required to bring the given board to its goal configuration.

getManhattanDistance

public static int getManhattanDistance(int value,
                                       int x,
                                       int y,
                                       int[][] solution)
Returns the manhattan distance for a tile at a given position.
The method will return the distance between the tile's given position (x, y) and the tile's destination.
The manhattan distance is a heuristic based on the shortest path between two tiles (dx + dy).

Parameters:
value - the value of a given tile.
x - the current column of a certain tile.
y - the current row of a certain tile.
solution - the board's goal position.
Returns:
the manhattan distance (shortest path) for the current tile.

readBoard

protected int[][] readBoard(java.io.Reader in)
                     throws java.io.IOException
Reads a board configuration from a Reader. A Reader could be connected to a file. The file should look like this: 

   4
   4
   1 5 2 3
   9 6 10 7
   4 8 0 11
   12 13 14 15

Where the first line represents the puzzle's width, the second its height and the rest of the lines represent the actual board configuration. The blank (open) tile is represented by the value 0 (zero). Note that the white spaces MUST be one or more spaces. Tabs are not allowed.

Parameters:
in - a Reader connected to a plain text file or other resource.
Returns:
the board configuration as it was read from the Reader.
Throws:
java.io.IOException - thrown whenever something went wrong parsing the board. Note that the parser is extremely picky and does often not give very helpful messages.
